column1: Lawrence is the county seat of Douglas County and sixth-largest city in Kansas. It is in the northeastern sector of the state
column2: astride Interstate 70
column3: between the Kansas and Wakarusa Rivers. As of the 2010 census
column4: the city's population was 87
column5: 643; by 2019 the estimated population had risen to 98
column6: 193. Lawrence is a college town and the home to both the University of Kansas and Haskell Indian Nations University.

column1: Lawrence was founded by the New England Emigrant Aid Company (NEEAC)
column2: and was named for Amos Adams Lawrence
column3: a Republican abolitionist originally from Massachusetts
column4: who offered financial aid and support for the settlement. Lawrence was central to the "Bleeding Kansas" period (1854–61)
column5: and the site of the Wakarusa War (1855) and the Sacking of Lawrence (1856). During the American Civil War it was also the site of the Lawrence massacre (1863).

column1: Lawrence began as a center of free-state politics. Its economy diversified into many industries
column2: including agriculture
column3: manufacturing
column4: and education
column5: beginning with the founding of the University of Kansas in 1865 and Haskell Indian Nations University in 1884.

column2: also known as the Kansa
column3: settled the region
column4: including what is now Lawrence in the late 17th or early 18th century. A series of treaties with the U.S. government compelled the Kaw to relinquish the land to the Shawnee and their Indian Reservation
column5: established in 1830. The Kansas Territory was established in May 1854. During this period
column6: the Oregon Trail ran parallel to the Kansas River
column7: roughly through the area where Lawrence is now. A hill in the area
column8: then known as Hogback Ridge and now known as Mount Oread
column9: which sits on the water divide separating the Kansas and Wakarusa River
column10: was used as a landmark and outlook by those on the trail. While the territory was technically closed to settlement until 1854
column11: there were a few "squatter settlements" in the area
column12: especially just north of the Kansas River.Lawrence was founded "strictly for political reasons" having to do with slavery
column13: which was heavily debated in the United States in the early to mid-1800s. Northern Democrats
column14: led by Senators Lewis Cass of Michigan and Stephen A. Douglas of Illinois
column15: promoted "popular sovereignty" as a middle position on the slavery issue. Its proponents argued that it was more democratic
column16: as it allowed the citizens of newly organized territories (and not Washington
column17: D.C. politicians) to have a direct say as to the legality of slavery in their own lands. (Meanwhile
column20: derisively called this idea "squatter sovereignty".) Douglas eventually made popular sovereignty the backbone of his Kansas–Nebraska Act—legislation that effectively repealed the Missouri Compromise of 1820 and created the territories of Kansas and Nebraska—which passed Congress in 1854.

column1: The Christian abolitionist and Protestant minister Richard Cordley later noted that after the bill became law
column2: "there was a feeling of despondency all over the north" because its passage "opened Kansas to [the possibility of] slavery [which many] thought [was] equivalent to making Kansas a slave state." This was largely because nearby Missouri allowed slavery
column3: and many rightly assumed that the first settlers in Kansas Territory would come from Missouri
column4: bringing their penchant for slavery with them. In time
column5: anger at the Kansas-Nebraska Act united antislavery forces into a movement committed to stopping the expansion of slavery
column6: eventually institutionalized as the Republican Party. Many slavery opponents decided to "meet the question [of slavery in Kansas] on the terms of the bill itself" by migrating to Kansas
column7: electing antislavery legislators
column8: and eventually banning slavery altogether. These settlers soon became known as "Free-Staters". Even before the bill passed
column9: some people already had this idea. In early May 1854
column10: four men—Thomas W. and Oliver P. Barber
column11: Samuel Walker
column12: and Thomas M. Pearson—toured the new territory with the intention of finding a good place to settle. Their travels included what would become Lawrence
column13: passing up on the spur of Hogback Ridge. The Kansas-Nebraska Act passed while they were in the territory
column14: and they were instrumental in convincing others to come. In his book A History of Lawrence (1895)
column15: Cordley wrote:

column1: The most systematic and extensive movement [to populate Kansas]
column2: however
column3: was made [by] "The New England Emigrant Aid Company" ... The men engaged in it
column4: Eli Thayer [a Republican in the United States House of Representatives]
column5: Amos A. Lawrence [a Republican abolitionist and businessman]
column6: and others
column7: began their work at once
column8: arousing public interest and making arrangements to facilitate emigration to Kansas. As early as June
column10: they sent Dr. Charles Robinson
column11: of Fitchburg
column12: and Mr. Charles H. Branscomb
column13: of Holyoke
column14: to explore the territory and select a site for a colony ... [Previously] Robinson [had journeyed to Kansas
column15: during which] his party climbed the hill along this spur
column16: and looked off over what was afterwards the site of Lawrence. They marked the beauty of the spot and the magnificence of the view. Whether they thought then of what might afterwards occur is not known; but when the time came to select a location for the first colony
column17: Dr. Robinson remembered this view from the hilltop
column18: and this doubtless had much to do in the final decision. When he was asked
column20: to go and explore the country with a view to locating colonies
column21: it was not altogether an unknown land to him.

column1: Branscomb was tasked with exploring the Kansas River up to about Fort Riley
column2: while Robinson scouted land near Fort Leavenworth and the nearby city of the same name; after assessing the territory they had surveyed
column3: the two recommended that the New England Emigrant Aid Company (NEEAC) send its settlers to claim territory along the Oregon Trail near Hogback Ridge. The two likely chose this site because it was the "first desirable location where emigrant Indians had ceded their land rights." The area was also attractive because it was close to not only on the Oregon Trail
column4: but also the Santa Fe and the 1846 Military Trails.

column1: Concurrent with Robinson and Branscomb's exploration
column2: the NEEAC was soliciting some of its members to settle in Kansas. At first
column3: the NEEAC wanted to send a somewhat sizeable group of settlers to claim the land
column4: but a cholera outbreak in the Missouri Valley prevented that. In the end
column5: a group of only 29 men—which Eli Thayer later called the "pioneer colony"—volunteered for the job. Led by Branscomb
column6: these pioneers left Boston
column7: Massachusetts
column8: and set out for Kansas Territory on July 17
column9: 1854; according to Thayer's antislavery newspaper the Kansas Crusader for Freedom
column10: "Immense crowds had gathered [in Boston] at the station to give them a parting God-speed. They moved out of the station amid the cheering of the crowds who lined the track for several blocks." In late July
column11: the group met Robinson in St. Louis
column12: and he discussed the next leg of the journey with them and provided them with transportation. The pioneers arrived in Kansas Territory near the end of July
column13: and at about noon on August 1
column14: they ate their first meal on Hogback Ridge itself
column15: which was soon renamed Mount Oread after the Oread Institute in Worcester
column16: Massachusetts. Immediately thereafter
column17: about half this party set off to claim land in the nearby countryside
column18: where about 15 of the original settlers remained
column19: and began to establish a city between Mount Oread and the Kansas River roughly where Massachusetts Street now runs.While all of this was unfolding
column21: guided by Robinson and Samuel C. Pomeroy (an abolitionist and a Republican member of the United States House of Representatives)
column24: on August 31; along the way to Kansas
column25: settlers of similar political inclinations joined this group
column26: and when the party reached its destination on September 9–11
column27: it had grown to about 114 people. This second party included about ten women
column29: and several musicians. A third group of settlers arrived in the vicinity of the future city on October 8–9
column30: but many "became disgusted by the outlook" of the settlement and returned to New England
column31: feeling they had been "deceived" by the NEEAC. A fourth group of settlers arrived on October 30
column32: followed by a fifth on November 20 and a sixth on December 1. On September 18
column33: the early colonists convened and established a "voluntary municipal government"
column35: the settlers had approved a constitution that included principles of prohibitionatory Maine law to govern their town. The settlement was created against threats by pro-slavery men that the free-staters ought to be "driven from the country." The first rally of forces from Lawrence was the night of September 30
column36: done to protect Thomas J. Ferril
column37: a free-state Methodist preacher from Missouri. His assailants had surrounded his house
column38: threatening violence and to destroy his property
column39: but retreated upon seeing a body of armed free-staters without injury to either side. The next day
column40: a woman tore down a free-state man's tent. Pro-slavery men rallied to prevent the tent's reconstruction by a group of about 20 armed free-staters
column41: but it was completed without violence. The next day
column42: a sizeable band of pro-slavery men appeared
column43: threatening a repeat of the attack
column44: but upon seeing their opponents ready
column45: they retreated with renewed threats of vengeance.When the settlers first arrived
column46: most had called their fledgling city simply Wakarusa
column47: after the nearby river of the same name
column49: such as New Boston (in recognition of both the NEEAC's city of operation and the hometown of many early settlers) and Plymouth (after Plymouth Rock). Meanwhile
column50: settlers from Missouri derisively called it "Yankee Town"
column51: due to its New England connections. Another name considered around this time was Lawrence. Many approved of this name in honor of Amos Adams Lawrence
column52: an Ipswich-based businessman and noted abolitionist
column55: was "a man of wide personal influence" and "one of the first men of means" to fund the Emigrant Aid Company. Others hoped that if they named their town after him
column56: Lawrence would be inclined to support them with monetary donations
column57: which proved correct. Another factor making "Lawrence" a popular choice was that it had "no bad odor attached to it in any part of the Union." On October 1
column58: the settlement's leaders voted to approve "Lawrence" as the name of their new city
column60: the citizens drew territory lots so as to begin erecting homes and businesses. Around this time
column61: the settlers got into a heated argument with pro-slavery squatters
column62: who were hoping to establish a city named Excelsior on the land where Lawrence was being constructed. These pro-slavers threatened violence against anyone who stood in their way
column63: but eventually acquiesced to the New Englanders
column64: and no open conflict occurred.In early October 1854
column65: the first governor of the Kansas Territory
column68: had a reception and a festival
column69: and after a welcoming speech by Pomeroy
column70: made a conciliatory speech urging harmony and order
column71: while evading the slavery question. Lawrence's first winter was characterized by great hardship
column72: as the people predominantly lived in sod houses and "shanties made of clap-boards." About two miles (3.3 km) south of Lawrence
column73: at the first election on November 3
column75: which was to elect only Congressional delegates
column76: there was a commotion; it ended with a man named Henry Davis attacking a pro-slavery man named Lucius Kibbee with a Bowie knife. The fight ended when Kibbee shot Davis
column77: making this Kansas's first homicide. While briefly incarcerated at Fort Leavenworth

column2: two newspapers touting the free state mission had been established in the town: the Herald of Freedom

column4: and the Kansas Pioneer

column10: a missionary sent to Kansas from Middletown
column11: New York. The first post office in Lawrence was established in January 1855
column12: and E. D. Ladd was appointed the town's first postmaster. On January 10
column14: the first school in Kansas was established in Lawrence by voluntary contributions
column15: and it was taught by Edward P. Fitch.

column2: settlers who held opposing opinions about slavery had settled in the Kansas Territory around the Lawrence area and began vying for political power. Secret societies
column3: called Blue Lodges
column4: were created
column5: and their sole purpose was to make Kansas a slave state. Their plan was to come into Kansas on the day of the election and vote so as to gain control of the legislature. Before the election
column6: a census was conducted. Kansas had a population of 8
column7: 601 with 2
column8: 905 of them being voters. Lawrence
column9: specifically
column10: had 369 voters. At the legislature election on March 30
column12: about 700–1
column13: 000 armed pro-slavery men from Missouri voted at the election. They came in over 100 wagons
column14: and they were armed with guns
column15: rifles
column16: pistols
column17: and Bowie knives. They also brought two pieces of artillery. Due to their large numbers
column18: they went unchallenged. They left for Missouri the next morning
column19: having camped in Lawrence the night before. Silas Bond was shot at and driven from the polls on the grounds that he was "an obnoxious free-state man." 1
column22: with 802 being from non-residents. There were only 2
column25: 307 votes were cast. The people appealed to Governor Andrew Reeder to set the election aside
column27: but after being threatened by pro-slavery people
column28: he decided instead to hold another election in districts in which there were protests
column29: such as Lawrence. The people of Lawrence felt this did nothing
column30: and many were uncertain about what would happen or what they needed to do.In June 1855
column31: a meeting was held in Lawrence
column32: at which resolutions were adopted intending to resist any laws that may be passed by the legislature
column33: and they declared that the legislature was elected by "armed usurpers from Missouri." This paved the way for a larger convention on June 25. Between June 8 and August 15
column35: seven meetings were held in Lawrence for the purposes of resisting the legislature. The free-state leaders sent George W. Deitzler to the east to secure weapons from other anti-slavery people. Amos Lawrence and others sent crates full of rifles
column36: to which they labeled "books" because "the border ruffians had no use for books
column37: [and] they came through without being disturbed." With the help of Horace Greeley
column38: a howitzer was sent to Lawrence. On August 27
column40: the proslavery faction in Douglas County (based primarily out of the territorial capital
column42: as well as smaller satellite settlements like Franklin and Lone Star) got a boost when acting territorial governor Daniel Woodson appointed the zealously proslavery settler Samuel J. Jones to the office of county sheriff. Then
column44: the outspoken abolitionist John Brown arrived in the Kansas Territory; he brought with him a wagon-load of weapons with which he intended to use to fight off "Satan and his legions" (i.e.
column46: the pro- and antislavery factions existed uneasily with one another. Then on November 21
column49: the proslavery settler Franklin N. Coleman shot the Free-Stater Charles Dow in the head
column50: killing him. The murder was the culmination of a long-simmering feud between the two
column51: as for some time they had bickered about a land claim near the Hickory Point post office
column52: located about 14 miles (23 km) south of Lawrence. According to the Border War Encyclopedia
column53: "Politics had not motivated Coleman to kill Dow
column54: but the murder marked the genesis of the violent political divisions that characterized Kansas for the next 10 years." When Jones investigated the crime
column55: Coleman argued that he had simply been acting in self-defense. The sheriff sided with his proslavery compatriot and chose to instead arrest Dow's free state affiliate Jacob Branson for disturbing the peace. Branson was quickly rescued by Samuel Newitt Wood and a gang of Free-Staters by breaking him out of jail. He was rescued at one in the morning
column56: just two hours after the arrest. As the gang of free-staters were heading back
column57: they were unsure of what to do. They consulted with Charles Robinson
column58: and they all realized that the pro-slavery people would label this act of breaking someone out of jail as an insurrection. They realized that the militia would be called to carry out the arrests of those who broke Branson out of jail
column59: but that they would likely use it as an excuse to destroy Lawrence. The rest of the city was unaware of the rescue at this time. It was decided that the men who broke Branson out of jail would need to keep out of the way. Robinson informed the others at a meeting of citizens that morning
column60: to which they agreed. They then started preparing the city for defense.

column1: To calm the increasingly belligerent settlers
column2: the governor of the Kansas Territory
column3: Wilson Shannon
column4: called on the Kansas militia to intervene and keep the peace. Shannon had intended for the militia to be composed of Kansans
column5: but Jones mustered a small army of 1
column7: 500 proslavery men
column8: all but about 50 came from Missouri. When the citizens of Lawrence learned of Jones's army
column9: they raised up a defensive militia of 600–800 men armed with "Beecher's Bibles". Robinson was chosen to direct the city's military operations
column10: the future state senator James Lane was selected as his second-in-command
column11: and a "committee of safety" was also created
column12: which organized squads of about 20 men to keep watch over the city. Lawrence was additionally aided by John Brown and his four sons: John Jr.
column13: Oliver
column14: Owen
column15: and Watson. Five forts of earthwork or rifle pits were constructed
column16: and a solid defense was prepared. While both sides were ready for a fight
column17: an outright clash between the two militias was prevented at least in part by the harsh Kansas winter. On December 8
column18: Shannon had had enough and ordered representatives from both sides to meet at the proslavery stronghold of Franklin to sign a peace treaty. Terms were agreed to
column21: the Missouri army reluctantly left the area. This conflict
column22: despite its rather diminutive size and scale
column23: would later be known as the "Wakarusa War".

column2: the proslavery forces
column3: hoping to diminish the power of the anti-slavery settlers
column4: singled out the Kansas Free State
column5: the Herald of Freedom
column6: and the Free State Hotel (the latter of which was owned and operated by the NEEAC) as "nuisances" that needed to be stopped. On April 23
column7: 1856 Sheriff Jones entered into Lawrence and attempted to arrest about a dozen members of the extralegal Free-State legislature (a rogue governing body which had been set up in opposition to the official proslavery territorial government). During the commotion
column8: Jones was non-fatally shot by a sniper named Charles Lenhart
column9: and Lawrence residents promptly drove the sheriff out of town. The people of Lawrence disavowed the act
column10: and they offered a $500 bounty for the sniper's arrest. A few weeks later
column11: on May 11
column12: Federal Marshal Israel B. Donaldson proclaimed the act had interfered with the legal execution of warrants against select antislavery settlers. This proclamation was bolstered by a Kansas grand jury's presentment that "the building known as the 'Free State' Hotel'  [sic] in Lawrence had been constructed with a view to military occupation and defence
column13: regularly parapetted and port holed
column14: for the use of cannon and small arms
column15: thereby endangering the public safety
column16: and encouraging rebellion and sedition in this country". Donaldson
column18: and Missouri senator David Rice Atchison consequently raised up another army comprising around 800 Southerners. Ostensibly this army's purpose was to enforce the legal arrest warrants
column19: but the group was also motivated by a desire to stamp out the Free-Stater nest that was Lawrence.On May 21
column20: Donaldson and Jones rode into town and successfully arrested those who had previously evaded them. While the citizens of Lawrence hoped that the officers would leave peacefully after making the arrests
column21: this did not come to pass. Donaldson dismissed his men
column22: who were immediately deputized by Jones. The sheriff was then joined by more followers and together they began to sack the city. After seizing the house of Charles Robinson (who had recently been arrested in Missouri
column23: and was held in prison near Lecompton on grounds of treason) to serve as his headquarters
column24: Jones and his men attacked the offices of the antislavery newspapers. The attackers smashed the presses
column25: tossed the type into the nearby Kansas River
column26: and threw already-printed copies of the newspapers into the wind. After this was done
column27: the proslavery mob shot the Free State Hotel with a cannon before burning it down. Jones and his men then pillaged $30
column28: 000 worth of valuables. When Jones left the city
column29: he and his men lit Robinson's house on fire for good measure. Although the city was thoroughly ransacked
column30: the human cost of the attack was low: only one person—a member of Jones's posses—died during the attack when he was struck by a piece of falling masonry. In late September 1856
column32: according to the Kansas State Board of Agriculture 1878 Biennial Report
column34: 700 proslavery men appeared in sight of Lawrence
column35: and the city was temporarily defended by Free-State men
column36: under the command of Maj. J. B. Abbott". However
column37: this threat was neutralized when the recently-installed territorial governor John W. Geary realized what was about to happen and called for federal reinforcements to defend the city.

column2: Lawrence received a charter from the proslavery government in Lecompton
column3: but the citizens
column4: being adamant in their opposition to the "Bogus Legislature"
column5: refused to accept it
column6: as it would have organized Lawrence under proslavery laws. In July 1857
column7: the citizens of Lawrence then attempted to secure an "official" city charter from the extralegal Free-State legislature before issuing one themselves. This act was seen as one of bold-faced insurrection by the newly-installed territorial governor Robert J. Walker; as a result
column8: on July 15
column9: 1857 Walker ordered William S. Harney to send a regiment of soldiers to watch over the city and impose martial law. These troops remained in the vicinity of Lawrence until the territorial elections in October of that year. By this time
column10: it seemed as if the struggles of Lawrence's early citizens were coming to fruition. In the election of 1857
column11: free-staters gained the upper hand and were able to oust the proslavery majority from the territorial legislature. By the start of the next year
column12: Samuel Jones—long the enemy of Lawrence's free state population—resigned his post as sheriff and left the territory. On January 16
column14: Lawrence was declared the seat of Douglas County (an honor that had previously belonged to Lecompton). In February of that year
column15: the legislature approved the city charter that had been drafted a little less than a year prior in July
column16: and soon James Blood became the first mayor of the city. Around this time
column17: the antislavery legislature often met in Lawrence
column18: which functioned as the de facto capital of Kansas Territory from 1858 until 1861 (although Lecompton was still the de jure seat of the governing body).

column1: === Kansas statehood and the American Civil War ===

column3: the Wyandotte Constitution was approved in a referendum by a vote of 10
column6: and after its approval by the U.S. Congress
column7: Kansas was admitted as a free state on January 29
column8: 1861. By the time the Wyandotte Constitution was framed in 1859
column9: it was clear that the proslavery forces had lost in their bid to control Kansas. But while Kansas's entrance into the Union as a free state arguably ended the Bleeding Kansas period
column10: it coincided with the outbreak of the American Civil War. Kansas's admission as a free state immediately followed the departure of the seceding states' pro-slavery congressmen
column11: who until then had blocked it.

column2: Lawrence became a stronghold for Jayhawker guerilla units (also known as "Red Legs")
column3: led by James Lane
column4: James Montgomery
column5: and "Doc" Jennison
column6: among others. These groups raided parts of western Missouri
column7: stealing goods and burning down farms; it was a common belief by Southerners that the goods snatched by these Jayhawkers were stored in Lawrence. On August 21
column9: Lawrence was attacked and destroyed by William Quantrill and hundreds of his irregular Confederate raiders. Most houses and businesses in Lawrence were burned and between 150 and 200 men and boys were murdered
column10: leaving 80 widows and 250 orphans. About $2
column12: 000 worth of property (equivalent to $41
column14: 730 in 2019) was destroyed. The Plymouth Congregational Church in Lawrence survived the attack
column15: but a number of its members were killed and its records were destroyed.Following Quantrill's raid
column16: the survivors and their Unionist allies began to clean up the damage and restore their settlement. After a very bitter winter that forced the citizens to temporarily put their work on hold
column18: and was completed with a zeal that Richard Cordley described as akin to "a religious obligation." Given the trauma of 1863
column19: the citizens of Lawrence were on edge during this period of rebuilding; Cordley notes
column20: "Rumors [of guerrilla attacks] were thick and the people [of Lawrence] were particularly sensitive to them." Consequently
column21: Lawrence citizens organized themselves into companies to protect the city. Around this time
column22: the federal government also erected several military posts on Mount Oread (among them Camp Ewing
column24: and Fort Ulysses) to keep guard over the city. However
column25: no further attacks were made on Lawrence
column26: and these installations were eventually abandoned and dismantled after the war.

column1: Attempts to begin a university in Kansas were first undertaken in 1855
column2: but it was only after Kansas became a state in 1861 that those attempts saw any real fruition. An institute of learning was proposed in 1859 as The University of Lawrence
column3: but it never opened. When Kansas became a state
column4: provision was included in the Kansas Constitution for a state university. From 1861 to 1863 the question of where the university would be located—Lawrence
column5: Manhattan or Emporia—was debated. On January 13
column7: Manhattan was made the site of the state's land-grant college
column8: leaving only Lawrence and Emporia as candidates. The fact Lawrence had $10
column9: 000 plus interest donated by Amos Lawrence plus 40 acres (160
column10: 000 m2) to donate for the university had great weight with the legislature. Eventually
column11: Lawrence beat out Emporia by one vote
column12: and in 1866
column13: the University of Kansas (KU) was opened to students.

column1: The first railroad that connected Lawrence was built in 1864
column2: starting from Kansas City. It was surveyed by the Union Pacific Railway
column3: Eastern Division
column4: and the first train to Lawrence traveled on November 28
column5: 1864. The first train to operate in Kansas south of the Kansas River did so by crossing the river in Lawrence on November 1

column1: Facing an energy crisis in the early 1870s
column2: the city contracted with Orlando Darling to construct a dam across the Kansas River to help provide the city with power. Frustrated with the construction of the dam
column3: Darling resigned and the Lawrence Land & Water Company completed the dam without him in 1873; however
column4: only when J.D. Bowersock took over the dam in 1879 that the constant damage to the dam ceased and repairs held up. The dam made Lawrence unique which helped in winning business against Kansas City and Leavenworth. The dam closed in 1968 but was reopened in 1977 with help from the city
column5: which wanted to build a new city hall next to the Bowersock Plant.The first wind-powered mill in Kansas was built in Lawrence in 1863 near the corner of what is now 9th Street and Emery Road. It was partially destroyed during Quantrill's Raid
column6: but it was rebuilt in 1864 at a cost of $9
column7: 700. It continued to be operational until July 1885
column8: but on April 30
column10: it was destroyed in a fire.In 1884 the United States Indian Industrial Training School was opened in Lawrence. Boys were taught the trades of tailor making
column11: blacksmithing
column12: farming and others while girls were taught cooking and homemaking. In 1887 the name was changed to the Haskell Institute
column13: after Dudley Haskell
column14: a legislator responsible for the school being in Lawrence. In 1993 the name was changed again to Haskell Indian Nations University.

column2: Watkins National Bank opened at 11th and Massachusetts. Founded by Jabez B. Watkins
column3: the bank would last until 1929. Watkin's wife Elizabeth donated the bank building to the city to use as a city hall. In 1970
column4: the city built a new city hall and after extensive renovations
column5: the bank reopened in 1975 as the Elizabeth M. Watkins Community Museum.In 1903
column6: the Kansas River flooded causing property damage in Lawrence
column7: especially North Lawrence. The water got as high as 27 feet and water marks can still be seen on some buildings especially at TeePee Junction at the U.S. 24–40 intersection and at Burcham Park. Lawrence would be hit by other floods in 1951
column8: where the water rose over 30 feet
column9: and in 1993 but with the reservoir and levee system in place
column10: Lawrence only had minimal damage compared to the other floods.Also in 1903
column11: Theodore Roosevelt visited Lawrence on his way to Manhattan where he gave a short speech and dedicated a fountain at 9th & New Hampshire. The fountain was later moved to South Park next to the gazebo. Roosevelt would visit Lawrence again in 1910 after visiting Osawatomie where he dedicated the John Brown State Historical Site and gave a speech on New Nationalism.In 1871
column12: the Lawrence Street Railway Company opened and offered citizens easy access to hotels and businesses along Massachusetts Street. The first streetcar was pulled by horses and mules and the track just ran along Massachusetts Street. After the 1903 flood
column13: the Kansas River bridge had to be rebuilt but was not considered safe for a streetcar to pass over. The Lawrence Street Railway Company closed later that year. In 1907
column14: C.L. Rutter attempted to bring back a bus system
column15: after having failed in 1902. In 1909
column16: a new streetcar system was implemented putting Rutter out of business and lasting until 1935. In 1909
column17: the streetcar company created Casey's Coaster (also known as Daisy's Dozer)
column18: a wooden roller coaster which lasted from 1909 to the 1920s
column20: Lawrence Memorial Hospital opened in the 300 block of Maine Street. It started with only 50 beds but by 1980
column21: the hospital would expand to 200. LMH has been awarded several awards and recognitions for care and quality including The Hospital Value Index Best in Value Award and is ranked nationally in the top five percent for heart attack care by the American College of Cardiology.In 1929 Lawrence began celebrating its 75th anniversary. The city dedicated Founder's Rock
column22: commonly referred to as the Shunganunga Boulder
column23: a huge red boulder brought to Lawrence from near Tecumseh. The rock honors the two parties of the Emigrant Aid Society who first settled in Lawrence. Lawrence also dedicated the Lawrence Municipal Airport on October 14.

column2: the federal government transported German and Italian prisoners of World War II to Kansas and other Midwest states to work on farms and help solve the labor shortage caused by American men serving in the war effort. Large internment camps were established in Kansas: Camp Concordia
column3: Camp Funston (at Fort Riley)
column4: Camp Phillips (at Salina under Fort Riley). Fort Riley established 12 smaller branch camps
column5: including Lawrence. The camp in Lawrence was near 11th & Haskell Avenue near the railroad tracks. The camp would close by the end of 1945.

column2: Gilbert Francis and his son George opened Francis Sporting Goods downtown
column3: selling mostly fishing and hunting gear. A decade later they moved across the street to larger retail space at 731 Massachusetts Street
column4: enabling them to expand into other sporting goods. In November 2014
column5: in the wake of the opening of a new Dick's Sporting Goods location in Lawrence

column9: Lawrence grabbed attention from the television movie The Day After. The TV movie first appeared on ABC but was later shown in movie theaters around the world. The movie depicted what would happen if the United States were destroyed in a nuclear war. The movie was filmed in Lawrence
column10: and hundreds of local residents appeared in the film as extras and in speaking roles.In 1989
column11: the Free State Brewing Company opened in Lawrence becoming the first legal brewery in Kansas in more than 100 years. The restaurant is in a renovated inter-urban trolley station in downtown Lawrence.

column1: The city lies on the southern edge of the Dissected Till Plains

column7: Kanwaka and Clinton Townships.

column1: Lawrence is located between the Kansas and Wakarusa Rivers. Several major creeks flow through Lawrence. Burroughs Creek in East Lawrence (named after the writer William S. Burroughs
column2: who retired in East Lawrence) and Baldwin Creek in northwestern Lawrence empty into the Kansas River. Yankee Tank Creek in southwest Lawrence and an unnamed creek that flows through central Lawrence converge with the Wakarusa River south of the city. Yankee Tank Creek is dammed to form Lake Alvamar
column3: which was originally called Yankee Tank Lake. The Wakarusa River was dammed to form Clinton Lake. Potter Lake is on the University of Kansas Campus and Mary's Lake is located in southeastern Lawrence within Prairie Park. The Haskell-Baker Wetlands
column4: maintained by Haskell University and Baker University
column5: is an extensive open space located in the southern part of the city that features wetlands
column6: native plants
column7: hiking and biking trails
column8: and interpretative signage about the prairie and wetland ecosystems.Lawrence has 54 parks which include community and neighborhood parks
column9: trails
column10: cemeteries and nature preserves. A new
column11: multi-use trail system called the Lawrence Loop ("the Loop") encircles the city and
column12: when fully completed
column13: will create a 22-mile paved recreational trail
column14: a green transportation network
column15: and multiple opportunities for environmental restoration. Community parks include South Park
column16: Buford Watson Park
column21: Centennial Park and Prairie Park. Cemeteries include Oak Hill
column22: Maple Grove and Memorial Park. The first cemetery in Lawrence
column24: is on the University of Kansas campus and is maintained by KU.

column1: Lawrence has a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa)
column2: typically experiencing hot
column3: humid summers and cold
column4: dry winters. The monthly daily average temperature ranges from 28.4 °F (−2.0 °C) in January to 78.5 °F (25.8 °C) in July. The high temperature reaches or exceeds 90 °F (32 °C) an average of 32 days a year and 100 °F (38 °C) an average of 1.9 days. The minimum temperature falls to or below 0 °F (−18 °C) on an average 4.9 days a year. Extreme temperatures range from 111 °F (44 °C) on July 13 and 14
column5: 1954 down to −21 °F (−29 °C) on December 22
column6: 1989.On average
column7: Lawrence receives 39.9 inches (1
column8: 010 mm) of precipitation annually
column9: most of which occurs in the warmer months
column10: and records 96 days of measurable precipitation. Measurable snowfall occurs an average of 8 days per year with 4.6 days receiving at least 1.0 inch (2.5 cm). Snow depth of at least one inch occurs an average of 15.8 days a year.

column1: The early settlers of the town named the city's main road "Massachusetts" to commemorate the New England Emigrant Aid Company's home state. Originally
column2: north–south streets were named after states in the order that they were admitted to the Union
column3: and east-west streets were named after famous Revolutionary War heroes. Over the years
column4: however

column6: North and South Carolina were consolidated into a single Carolina Street near Lawrence High School
column7: and the names of nine states (Alaska
column8: Georgia
column9: Hawaii
column10: Idaho
column11: Nevada
column12: New Mexico
column13: Texas
column14: Washington and Wyoming) were never given to streets. The state street naming system was abandoned after the establishment of Iowa Street
column15: which runs through the center of Lawrence. In 1913
column16: the east-west streets were renamed to numbered streets.

column1: The architecture of Lawrence is greatly varied. Most buildings built before 1860 were destroyed in the Lawrence Massacre. Architectural styles represented in Lawrence's historical areas are Victorian

column1: Lawrence has a diverse economy spanning education
column2: industrial
column3: agricultural
column4: government
column5: finance and scientific research
column6: most of these are related to the University of Kansas
column7: which is the largest employer in Lawrence. The largest private employer in Lawrence is General Dynamics. Lawrence Public Schools
column8: the City of Lawrence
column9: Lawrence Memorial Hospital and Hallmark Cards round out the top six employers.Lawrence saw growth in the industrial sector in the 1980s in part to the development of the East Hills Business Park in 1986. The industrial land opportunities provided by the East Hills Business Park provided space for national companies such as AMARR Garage Doors to house one of their two manufacturing facilities. The new industrial park also provided opportunities for Kansas City-based companies such as PROSOCO to move their business operations to Lawrence.

column1: South Park is a large park in Downtown Lawrence divided by Massachusetts Street just south of the county courthouse between North Park and South Park Streets. The park originally consisted of four separate parks—Lafayette
column2: Hamilton
column3: Washington and Franklin Parks—but was combined to form one park. South Park was developed in 1854 as part of the original city plat. A gazebo was built in South Park in 1910 and is used for annual city band performances during the summer months.The Watkins Museum of History is a block north of South Park and houses exhibits from Lawrence and Douglas County. The building is managed by the Douglas County Historical Society and used to be Watkins National Bank (1888–1929) and Lawrence City Hall (1929–1970). The building features a range of architectural styles from the period it was constructed. Today it houses the Watkins Museum of History
column4: which offers free admission and three floors of traditional and computer interactive exhibits. Next door to the museum is a Japanese Friendship Garden designed by the city and representatives from sister city Hiratsuka
column5: Japan. An exhibit on the Bleeding Kansas era and the Freedom's Frontier National Heritage Area is in the old Lawrence Public Library at 9th and Vermont Streets. Other museums on KU campus include the Natural History Museum in Dyche Hall
column6: the Spencer Museum of Art and the Dole Institute of Politics among others.Centennial Park
column7: between 6th and 9th Streets and Rockledge Road and Iowa Street
column8: was established in 1954 for the city's 100th anniversary. The park features rolling hills
column9: a skatepark
column10: a disc golf course and a Polaris missile constructed during the Cold War. Sesquicentennial Park is near Clinton Lake and was established for Lawrence's 150th anniversary and is mostly undeveloped but features a timeline of Lawrence history and a time capsule to be opened in 2054.Liberty Hall was built when the Bowersock Opera House burned down in 1911. Liberty Hall is a theater typically showcasing independent movies and frequent live acts. Liberty Hall also runs a video rental next door. The Granada Theater was originally built in 1928 as a vaudeville theater. It was renovated in 1934 as a movie theater until closing in 1989. It was renovated again in 1993 and opened as a venue for comedy acts and live music.

column1: The Eldridge Hotel was first built in 1855 as the Free State Hotel. During the 1855 sack of Lawrence
column2: the hotel was burned to the ground
column3: and its ruins were purchased by Col. Shalor Eldridge
column4: who rebuilt it and named it the Eldridge House. This version of the structure was destroyed during Quantrill's Raid
column5: but once again Eldridge rebuilt it. In 1925
column6: this structure was completely renovated
column7: and in 1970
column8: the hotel was converted into apartments. In 1985
column9: work began to renovate the Eldridge and turn it back into a hotel
column10: and in 2004 the building was sold and completely renovated back to its 1925 look. It is a popular rumor that the ghost of Eldridge haunts the hotel.Memorial Stadium and Allen Fieldhouse are on KU campus. Memorial Stadium was built in 1920 for the Kansas Jayhawks football program. It was named to honor KU students who died in World War I. Allen Fieldhouse was built in 1955 for the basketball program and was named for Phog Allen
column11: a coach at KU from 1907 to 1909 and 1919 to 1956. On November 4
column13: the ESPN's online publication
column14: The Magazine
column15: named Allen Fieldhouse the loudest college basketball arena in the country
column16: whilst prominent sportswriter
column18: has publicly declared the fieldhouse is "the best place in America to watch college basketball."Oak Hill Cemetery in east Lawrence was established in 1866 and was called by William Allen White the "Kansas Arlington." The cemetery features the burials of James Lane
column21: numerous veterans and many prominent Kansans. Across the street is Memorial Park Cemetery which features a memorial for KU coach and inventor of basketball James Naismith. The memorial is a cenotaph but Naismith is buried in the mason section of Memorial Park.Lawrence is also the site of many historic houses related to the history of the city. The Robert Miller house survived Quantrill's Raid and was a stop on the Underground Railroad
column24: built his house atop of Windmill Hill in what is now the Hillcrest Neighborhood and the John Roberts House
column25: commonly called the Castle Tea Room
column26: was designed by famed architect John G. Haskell in 1894 and is now used for various formal events. There are many other houses of historic prominence in Lawrence
column27: many of them on the National Register of Historic Places.

column1: The city is known for a thriving music and art scene. Rolling Stone named Lawrence one of the "best lil' college towns" in the country in its August 11
column3: issue. The New York Times said Lawrence had "the most vital music scene between Chicago and Denver" in a travel column on February 25
column4: 2005. Locally owned bar and music venue The Replay Lounge was named one of Esquire magazine's top 25 bars/venues in the country in 2007.The Lied Center of Kansas is known for presenting Broadway musicals
column5: internationally touring dance companies and many headline artists such as The Beach Boys
column6: Kristin Chenoweth
column7: Lyle Lovett and Kansas.In December 2005

column12: March 28
column13: April 1
column14: July 15
column15: August 2
column16: August 7
column24: determined by rolling dice and pulling numbers out of a hat.Lawrence is home to many bands and record labels. Many artists
column37: The Esoteric and The Get Up Kids originated in Lawrence or its surrounding areas. KJHK 90.7 FM
column38: the University of Kansas's student-run radio station
column39: is a staple of the local music scene. It won a CMJ award in 2006 for "most improved station
column40:
and it was nominated for a Plug Award for best college radio station in 2007.

The Wakarusa Music and Camping Festival was a four-day-long weekend music festival held annually in early June just outside Lawrence, at Clinton State Park. After its inception in 2004, the festival grew dramatically by 2006, with almost 60,000 tickets sold, and developed a nationwide following that accounted for 80% of ticket sales. The festival featured an eclectic mix of music, with artists like The Flaming Lips, Wilco, STS9, Medeski, Martin and Wood, Neko Case, and Widespread Panic taking the stage. The event is kept smaller than other festivals such as Bonnaroo by an agreement with the state. Activities other than music include disc golf, yoga, hiking, and swimming in Clinton Lake. The festival was relocated to Mulberry Mountain due to a dispute between the organizers and the Kansas Department of Wildlife and Parks over limiting attendees and over rent payment.Lawrence is home to the Gunn Center for the Study of Science Fiction, the first research center in the world dedicated to science fiction studies. Since 1969, the center has offered courses and workshops in science fiction literature and writing, hosted an annual conference, brought speakers to Lawrence, and presented multiple annual awards and scholarships.Every year since 1959, on the third Thursday of July there is the Massachusetts Street sidewalk sale
column41:
which most businesses on Massachusetts Street offer discounts on their merchandise. The sale is often supplemented by band performances or radio stations playing during the event.


== Sports ==

Lawrence is also the home of the University of Kansas (KU) athletic teams. The perennially highly ranked Kansas Jayhawks basketball team (1922 and 1923 Helms Foundation National Champions and 1952, 1988, and 2008 NCAA Champions) is closely followed by most residents during the winter. Massachusetts Street, the primary street of downtown Lawrence, flooded with fans in 2002, 2003, 2008, and 2012 after both KU's victories and defeats in the final rounds of the NCAA tournaments those years. KU's football team had their best record in their school history in the 2007–2008 season going 12–1 and culminating with a victory in the Orange Bowl. The city honored the university's mascot, the Jayhawk, in 2003 when 30 statues of Jayhawks were commissioned by the Lawrence Convention and Visitors Bureau; these can be seen throughout the city as part of an art installation called Jayhawks on Parade." The Jayhawks also field a soccer team
column45: and a men's club hockey team. KU also has a club rugby team
column46: run by the KU Rugby Football club
column47: with a clubhouse in North Johnny's Tavern. They also run the high school and the club team.

column1: Lawrence is run by a city commission and city manager. Commissioners consists of five individuals elected by the citizens. Three commissioner seats are up for reelection every two years. The two top vote-getters receive a four-year term
column2: third-place finisher receives a two-year term. The commission elects a mayor and vice-mayor every year in April
column3: usually the two top vote-getters
column4: and also hires the city manager. Lawrence uses plurality-at-large voting (also known as block voting) for its municipal elections
column5: whereby voters may choose up to three candidates for office.While Kansas is a heavily Republican state
column6: Lawrence is often considered a bastion of the modern Democratic Party
column7: and has been since the late 1980s. Douglas County
column8: where Lawrence is situated
column9: was one of only two counties in Kansas whose majority voted for John Kerry in the 2004 presidential election
column10: one of only three that voted for Barack Obama in the 2008 election and one of the only two counties to vote for Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential election. Douglas County has supported the Democratic candidate for the past seven presidential elections.Lawrence is served by Democratic state representatives Eileen Horn
column11: Mike Amyx
column12: Barbara Ballard and Dennis "Boog" Highberger
column13: and by Democratic state senators Marci Francisco
column14: and Tom Holland. Lawrence is represented federally by Republican Steve Watkins of the 2nd and U.S. Senators Pat Roberts and Jerry Moran
column15: both Republicans. Prior to 2002
column16: Lawrence sat entirely within the 3rd district until reapportionment split Lawrence between the 2nd and 3rd districts. In 2012
column17: Lawrence was placed entirely within the 2nd district.Lawrence was the first city in Kansas to enact an ordinance (enacted in 1995
column18: after a campaign called Simply Equal) prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. On October 4
column20: Lawrence became the first city in Kansas to prohibit discrimination based on gender identity with the passage of City Ordinance No. 8672. The effort to pass the GIO was led by Scott Criqui from the Kansas Equality Coalition. Scott Criqui would go on to become the first openly gay candidate to run for office and win an election in Lawrence. Douglas County was the only county in Kansas to reject the amendment to the Kansas Constitution prohibiting both gay marriage and civil unions in April 2005. The vote against the amendment was primarily in the city of Lawrence; outside the city in the rest of Douglas County
column21: the amendment carried. Lawrence has an active chapter of the Kansas Equality Coalition
column22: which persuaded the city commission to approve a domestic partner registry on May 22
column26: provides unmarried couples —both same-sex and other-sex— some recognition by the city for legal purposes.

column7: and Lawrence High School leads the State of Kansas in most state championships won

column11: and the interdenominational Veritas Christian School. There is also St. John Catholic School
column12: which teaches grades Pre-K through eight and is funded by the Catholic communities of Lawrence and Corpus Christi Catholic School. Raintree Montessori School is a secular private school which teaches preschool through grade eight. The Prairie Moon School is a Waldorf school near Lawrence. The city has 15 public schools: Langston Hughes Elementary

column1: The University of Kansas is the largest public university in the state with total enrollment of just more than 30
column2: 000 students (including approximately 3
column3: 000 students at the KU Medical Center in Kansas City
column4: KS). A Big 12 school
column5: the University of Kansas has more than 170 fields of study and the nationally known Kansas Jayhawks athletics programs. Haskell Indian Nations University offers free tuition to members of registered Native American tribes. However
column6: students are required to pay semester fees similar to many other colleges in the United States. It has an average enrollment of more than 1
column7: 000 (with students hailing from all 50 U.S. states and from over 150 tribes). Haskell University is also the home of the American Indian Athletic Hall of Fame and the Haskell Cultural Center. Several private Christian colleges and schools are located in Lawrence as well
column8: such as Heritage Baptist College.In 2011
column9: Lawrence was named one of America's 10 best college towns by Parents & Colleges. Lawrence also was included in lists of top college towns in 2010 by the American Institute for Economic Research

column1: The first library in Lawrence was started in October 1854 and was a subscription library costing $1 a year. After the Lawrence massacre destroyed the library
column2: a new one was started in 1865 and placed under city jurisdiction in 1871. In 1902
column3: Peter Emery successfully got a grant from Andrew Carnegie to build a new library at 9th and Vermont Streets. The Lawrence Public Library opened in 1904. A new library to replace the aging and outdated Carnegie Building was completed in 1972 at 7th and Vermont Streets with voters approving a bond issue in 2010 to expand and update the building. During construction
column4: the library moved to 7th and New Hampshire in the former Borders bookstore. The new library opened in July 2014.The Lawrence Public Library was one of seven libraries in the United States that won the AIA/ALA Library Building Award in 2016.

column4: and KU on Wheels is operated by the University of Kansas. Together
column5: the two systems operate 18 bus routes in the city. Both systems are free to KU students
column6: faculty
column7: and staff. Both systems are owned and operated by MV Transportation. Greyhound Lines provides intercity bus service with a stop in Lawrence. In addition
column8: the Johnson County
column9: Kansas bus system provides inter-city transport between Lawrence and Overland Park college campuses in a route known as the K-10 Connector.Lawrence Municipal Airport is northeast of the city
column10: immediately north of U.S. 40. Publicly owned
column11: it has two runways and is used for general aviation. The nearest airport with commercial airline service is Kansas City International Airport which is approximately 50 miles northeast of downtown Lawrence.Two Class I railroads
column12: BNSF Railway and Union Pacific Railroad (UP)
column13: have lines which pass through Lawrence. The BNSF line enters the city from the east and exits to the north
column14: roughly following the course of the Kansas River. The UP line does the same on the north side of the river
column15: running through the city's northeast corner. Using the BNSF trackage
column16: Amtrak provides passenger rail service on its Southwest Chief line between Chicago and Los Angeles. Amtrak's Lawrence station is a few blocks east of downtown.According to the 2017 American Community Survey
column17: 76.6% of working city of Lawrence residents commuted by driving alone
column20: and 6.0% walked. About 2.0% used all other forms of transportation
column23: and bicycle. About 3.8% of working city of Lawrence residents worked at home. In 2017
column24: 2.5% of city of Lawrence households were without a car. 77.3% of city of Lawrence residents also work in Lawrence.Lawrence ranked 62nd in the United States for the highest percentage of commuters by bicycle in 2011 at 1.73%.

column2: the non-profit community-owed Lawrence Memorial Hospital. The hospital has been awarded several awards and recognitions for care and quality including The Hospital Value Index Best in Value Award
column3: and it is ranked nationally in the top five percent for heart attack care by the American College of Cardiology.The most predominant electric provider is Evergy
column4: and the most predominant gas provider is Black Hills Energy. Midco and DirecTV are the major television providers. Internet providers include Midco
column5: Wicked Broadband
column6: CenturyLink
column7: Exede and Wildblue Internet Service
column8: HughesNet
column9: Allconnect
column10: and ViaSat Satellite. There are numerous telephone service providers in Lawrence
column11: including Midco
column12: AT&T
column13: Sprint
column14: Verizon
column15: and others.

column1: Snow removal services are provided by the Lawrence Street Maintenance Division
column2: who is also responsible for maintaining the city's streets
column3: curbs
column4: alleys
column5: and gutters
column6: the Kansas River and Mud Creek levee
column7: some of the infrastructure of the Lawrence Municipal Airport
column8: and street sweeping.

column2: Schleswig-Holstein
column3: Germany – October 27

column3: Japan – September 21

column1: The city served as the setting for a number of science fiction writer James Gunn's novels
column2: including The Immortals (1964)
column3: which was the basis for the ABC television movie and TV series The Immortal (1969–1971).

column1: Lawrence was a setting in the 1983 television movie The Day After
column2: and parts of the movie were filmed in the city.Sam and Dean Winchester
column3: the protagonists of the Supernatural TV series
column4: are from Lawrence
column5: and the city has been referenced numerous times throughout the show's history. Eric Kripke
column6: the creator of Supernatural
column7: decided to have the two brothers be from Lawrence because of its closeness to Stull Cemetery
column8: a location famous for its urban legends. Lawrence was destroyed in the 2006 TV Series Jericho.American folk singer Josh Ritter's song entitled Lawrence KS is on the 2002 album Golden Age of Radio. Cross Canadian Ragweed's 2007 album Mission California features a song entitled "Lawrence
column9: which was inspired by a homeless family the band encountered near Christmas while visiting the town.Lawrence's Meadowbrook Apartments residential complex is the default starting point for the map program Google Earth. This location was set by Brian McClendon, a 1986 graduate of the University of Kansas and director of engineering for Google Earth, who lived in the complex as a child.The 1985 Electro (music) album Street Sounds Electro 10 features a track by '19th Fleet' entitled 'Star Raid', which opens with a radio operator calling, This is Lawrence Kansas... Do you read me? Is anyone still alive?" as the song has a science fiction theme.
